title: 104_hr3434
content: The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" limits representation or advising of certain foreign entities. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" restricts individuals from representing foreign entities within 10 years after their government service ends. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" prohibits individuals from representing foreign entities within 5 years after their government service ends. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" prohibits individuals from representing foreign entities within 5 years after their government service ends, unless the individual is a U.S. citizen or the entity is organized under U.S. laws and has its principal place of business in the U.S. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" prohibits individuals from representing foreign entities within 5 years after their government service ends, unless the entity is organized under U.S. laws and has its principal place of business in the U.S. Persons who provide representation or advice related to matters in which the United States is involved will be punished according to section 216 of this title. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" prohibits individuals from representing foreign entities within 5 years after their government service ends. Persons who provide representation or advice related to matters involving the United States will be punished as provided in section 216 of this title. The restrictions apply to the President of the United States and individuals subject to subsection (c), (d), or (e). Compensation refers to any payment, gift, benefit, reward, favor, or gratuity. The term 'compensation' refers to any payment, gift, benefit, reward, favor, or gratuity provided for services rendered. The definitions of 'government of a foreign country' and 'foreign political party' are specified in the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938. The term 'United States' refers to the several states. The Agents Registration Act of 1938 defines terms like 'United States' and 'State'. The amendment made by subsection (a) takes effect on January 1, 1997. The amendment made by subsection (a) takes effect on January 1, 1997 and does not apply to individuals whose service ended before that date. SEC. 3. CROSS-OVER LOBBYING. The amendment to Section 207(d) of title 18, United States Code imposes additional restrictions on former executive branch officers or employees who knowingly attempt to influence members of Congress or legislative branch employees within 1 year of leaving their government position. Any former Member of Congress or employee of the House of Representatives or Senate with a salary over 120 percent of the minimum rate for GS-15 who attempts to influence the legislative branch within 1 year of leaving their position will face punishment under section 216. Former Members of Congress or employees of the House of Representatives or Senate with salaries over 120 percent of the minimum rate for GS-15 who attempt to influence the executive branch within 1 year of leaving their position will be punished under section 216. SEC. 4. FELONS. Section 207 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit convicted felons who are former Members of Congress, former high-salary employees of the House or Senate, or certain executive branch employees from making any compensated communication or appearance before House employees. Convicted felons who are subject to subsection (c) or (d) may not make any compensated communication or appearance before employees of the House of Representatives, Senate, or executive branch of the United States. SEC. 5 amends the Foreign Agents Registration Act regarding lobbying activities. SEC. 6 addresses civil penalties. SEC. 6 of the Foreign Agents Registration Act introduces civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation knowingly committed.
